title: Motivation + Methodologies
text:
Main Goals

Start from the basic question: What is the likelihood that a given asset’s price will rise or fall in the next few months?
Find the most meaningful forward-looking information for asset prices. In the spirit of the most thoughtful global macro analytical approaches, incorporate loosely-correlated features that dimension various drivers of asset price formation: policy expectations, cyclical data evolution, cyclically sensitive asset dynamics, various risk premia, cross-asset class dynamics, etc.
Use a machine-learning apparatus to aggregate these data into one summary metric. Prioritize interpretability and consistency to increase confidence in live performance.

Why?

The world is awash with research, commentary and anecdotal observations about asset prices. Tools like TradingView have enabled countless to dabble in the necromancy of technical analysis.
Still, it is exceedingly rare to find the sort of analysis that takes a multifaceted approach; which conditions the overall view on the direction of prices on the state of many different drivers. In fact, the celebrated gut feel of well-known traders and investors may be a form of multi-dimensional analysis along these lines, which through experience and time, becomes instinct.
We have data at a high frequency for multiple decades making today a better time than ever for a more thorough investigation.


Brief Illustrated Methodology:

Start with the raw price series.  Turn it into connecting linear segments. It’s less noisy like this.  The linear segments move up or down, which determines the two regimes highlighted below.  Features used to predict regimes capture various relevant asset price drivers. Let’s make them comparable with some initial pre-processing. We will use lagged versions of these features to predict asset price regimes, enabling us to look forward at the risks of price increases or declines in coming months.
 Now we can calibrate model parameters with a gradually expanding training window. Many performance approaches exist. One is to save the last, more recent part of our dataset from any modeling work and compare metrics on this live set with the calibration test sets.
  Finally, let’s examine regime predictions which summarise the risk of a given asset’s price rising or falling. Daily probability estimates arrive in advance of actual price action.

title: About + Links
text:
About

The work undertaken here is informed by a decade and a half of tinkering, refining and experimenting with asset prices, their drivers and a coherent, consistent system for their analysis. That includes time at large global macro funds, one of the largest asset managers globally and at a central bank as well participating in the Numer.ai competition for 5+ years.
Nonetheless, markets don’t care about any of that. The quality of the work should speak for itself.

Links

Underlying data sourced from: Yahoo Finance, Bank of England, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, CoinMetrics, Etherscan
All work in R. Charting via dygraphs. Site built with Quarto
Numerai
Introductory Econometrics for Finance
Macrosynergy, formely Sr-Sv
Research Papers: Principal Components as a Measure of Systemic Risk/ Many of Rob Hyndman’s publications
